Award.AwardTitle: ERASynBio: Technologies to Enable BioMolecular Origami

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program in MCB and the Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering Program in CBET, is part of a larger ERASynBio funded collaborative. The team of investigators will develop the rules that govern the design of complex nanometer scale structures made from nucleic acids and polypeptides, and use those rules to create new biological molecules that have never been seen before in nature. They will also develop the tools that will enable the assembly of these new materials that could potentially be used to control many aspects of cell function, or create new materials that could be used as sensors or in biomanufacturing.

Technical: Biological organisms are capable of producing chemicals, materials and molecular machines that far exceed our engineering capabilities. Underlying these abilities are the unique properties of proteins, exquisitely evolved for function, allowing precise positioning of atoms and chemistries. Designing novel proteins is difficult because of our still incomplete understanding of how proteins fold for a given primary amino-acid sequence. In this project, researchers will apply principles of synthetic biology to define and modularize building blocks that can be combined in rational ways to enable control of 3D positioning in designed macromolecular structure. Members of the consortium have advanced design and engineering principles for polypeptide- and DNA-based nanostructures and developed next-generation gene synthesis to facilitate high-throughput approaches. The team will build on these foundations to engineer bio-macromolecular assemblies with shapes and functions of unprecedented complexity. They will deliver an expanded toolbox of polypeptide building elements; rules, design principles and methods for constructing complex bionanostructures; and routes to nucleic acid/ polypeptide-hybrid platforms for the community of synthetic biology. The project will expand the limits of the designed polypeptide and nucleic acid/protein hybrid providing a platform to facilitate their use in a wide range of biomanufacturing applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative work was intended to develop base technologies that would allow us to better understand and engineer protein-protein interactions in order to build designed protein nanostructures. Here, we have built a new system that lets us design, synthesize, and assay tens of thousands of interactions at the same time. Briefly, we leveraged an old protein-complementation system using adenylate cyclase, where if two proteins come together, they reconstitute activity of a protein that produces cyclic AMP.  We can use a transcription factor that is responsive to this cyclic AMP to print out a barcode in RNA that identifies the two protein components interacting.  Thus, the barcode sequence identifies which two components interact, and the expression level measures how strongly they are interacting. We then use DNA microarrays to print the DNA of the proteins we wish to test, and integrate them into this assay in a pooled manner allowing us to do large-scale design and analysis work at unprecedented scale. We have shown we can scale this system to tens of thousands of simultaneously measured interactions at once. We have exploited this platform in collaboration with Roman Jerala's group (Slovenia) in order to constrain models for how this simple system interacts by building very large datasets that explore individual parameters in our models. Using this system, we have developed large libraries of interacting protein components that can now be used to build defined nanostructures using proteins. This well-behaved set of molecular components can be reused across many different nanostructures in time, and our system allows for the systematic exploration of such interactions at unprecedented scale. In addition, we are now extending this system to understand how natural coiled coils establish specificity and orthogonality over the course of evolution. More broadly, our ability to build rationally designed components to drive nanostructure design in proteins can open new horizons towards engineered materials that we are just beginning to explore.

 


Last Modified: 10/31/2018
Modified by: Sriram Kosuri
